case_data.name: Vangala v. USCIS
case_data.plaintiff_description: Three noncitizens on behalf of themselves and all individuals who had been or would be harmed by a who were harmed by USCIS's "blank space"/"rejection" policy
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
On November 19, 2020, three noncitizens filed a class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (“USCIS”) and the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (“DHS”) on behalf of themselves and all individuals who had been or would be harmed by a USCIS policy that required applicants for immigration benefits to fill in every response field on their applications, even fields that did not apply to them. This “blank space” policy led USCIS to reject thousands of applications. Some rejected applications had only one blank response field. Others included the phrase “not applicable” in lieu of “N/A,” another policy violation. USCIS also failed to notify applicants when their applications were rejected. Consequently, many benefit seekers––including abandoned and abused children, survivors of domestic violence and human trafficking, and asylum seekers––missed deadlines and lost the ability to obtain benefits for themselves, their children, and other family members.

Represented by National Immigration Litigation Alliance (NILA), Northwest Immigrant Rights Project (NWIRP), and private counsel, the plaintiffs sued USCIS and DHS under the Administrative Procedure Act and the Declaratory Judgment Act. The government allegedly violated the APA by failing to provide a reasoned explanation for the blank space policy, failing to follow proper procedures when adopting the policy, and defying USCIS regulations. The plaintiffs argued that the policy served no legitimate purpose and was adopted only to prevent vulnerable immigrants from obtaining immigration benefits. Per the complaint, the plaintiffs sought an injunction prohibiting USCIS from enforcing the policy and requiring USCIS to notify individuals whose applications were rejected as a result of it. The plaintiffs also moved for class certification the same day that the complaint was filed. The case was assigned to Judge Haywood S. Gilliam, Jr.

On January 14, 2021, Judge Gilliam, Jr., granted a stipulation by both parties to temporarily halt the proceedings to allow pending settlement talks to continue. The stay was extended on February 18 and again on March 25.

On July 19, 2021, the parties filed a joint motion asking the court to approve their settlement agreement. The agreement, which was attached to the motion as an exhibit, provided that USCIS had rescinded the No Blank Space Rejection Policy as of December 23, 2020, would allow people who were rejected under the policy to resubmit for the same benefit within a year of the date the settlement became effective, would review documents that were initially rejected and resubmitted as having been submitted on the original submission date, and would notify people rejected under the policy of their ability to resubmit for the denied benefits. The court approved the settlement agreement on July 20, 2021, and the case was closed on August 10, 2021.
case_data.summary_short: On November 19, 2020, three noncitizens filed a class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services and the U.S. Department of Homeland Security on behalf of themselves and all individuals who had been or would be harmed by USCIS’s “blank space” policy, which required applicants for immigration benefits to fill in every response field on their applications, even fields that did not apply to them. The parties reached a settlement to end the policy, allow people rejected under it to be considered for benefits, and notify those who had been rejected of their new eligibility.
case_data.summary_tiny: Immigration advocates, USCIS reach settlement to end No Blank Space Rejection Policy, provide denied benefits, notify those whose applications were previously denied under the policy (N.D. Cal.)

Case 3:20-cv-08143   Document 1   Filed 11/19/20   Page 2 of 31
 
1  INTRODUCTION 
2 
1.  In late 2019, without notice to the public, Defendant U.S. Citizenship and 
3 
Immigration Services (USCIS) implemented a tectonic shift in immigration adjudications requiring 
4 
its employees to arbitrarily reject thousands of applications from vulnerable immigrants. Notably, 
5 
USCIS’s new policy targeted applications seeking humanitarian benefits: from those seeking 
6 
refuge from persecution (asylum applications), survivors of domestic violence and other crimes

1  II.  USCIS’s Instructions Regarding the Application and Receipt Process 
2 
37.  USCIS publishes written instructions for completing forms for immigration 
3 
benefits, such as Form I-589, Form I-918, Form I-914, Form I-360, and Form I-751. These 
4 
published instructions go through notice and comment procedures and are available with the forms 
5 
on the USCIS website.  
6 
38.  The instructions are incorporated into the regulations governing the submission of 
7 
8  each form and therefore carry the force of law. 8 C.F.R. § 103.2(a)(1). 
9  39.  For the vast majority of USCIS forms, including those at issue in this case, an 
10 
application is submitted to USCIS by sending a completed paper copy of the application form, 
11 
with supporting documentation, to a specific USCIS office. If USCIS accepts the application form, 
12 
USCIS sends the applicant a Notice of Action on Form I-797C acknowledging its receipt of the 
13 
application (including any supplements) “as of the actual date of receipt.” 8 C.F.R. 
14 
§ 103.2(a)(7)(i).  
15 
16  40.  If the application is missing evidence, the governing regulations provide that 
17 
USCIS may either: (a) deny the benefit; (b) request that the applicant or petitioner submit more 
18 
information or evidence by a date certain (Request for Evidence, or RFE); or (c) notify the 
19 
applicant or petitioner of an intent to deny the benefit and require a response by a date certain 
20 
(Notice of Intent to Deny, or NOID). 8 C.F.R. § 103.2(b)(8)(ii), (iii). 
21 
41.  RFEs or NOIDs “specify the type of evidence required” to establish eligibility for 
22 
23  the immigration benefit. Id. § 103.2(b)(8)(iv). USCIS sends these documents through regular or 
24  electronic mail. 
25 
42.  When USCIS follows the governing regulatory RFE or NOID process, it does not 
26 
reject the application. Rather, USCIS treats the application filed as of the date of receipt and 
27 
provides a date certain by which an applicant must submit the missing information or evidence.

13 
92.  The impact of the rejection policy on applications for immigration benefits has been 
14 
significant and widespread. In many cases, the policy has led to dire consequences for 
15 
16  exceptionally vulnerable individuals and families. Specifically, the rejection policy has prevented 
17 
applicants from complying with the rigid statutory timelines governing deadlines and eligibility 
18 
based on the age of the applicant or family member. As a result, many applicants have been or will 
19 
be unable to secure a humanitarian benefit for themselves or for their families.  
20 
93.  Extensive processing delays compound the harm caused by the rejection policy. 
21 
USCIS routinely takes weeks to process the applications it receives and to determine whether to 
22 
23  accept or reject the submission. It often takes USCIS at least a month to inform an applicant that it 
24  has rejected an application. The applicant (or their attorney, if any) must then refile the amended 
25 
application, a process which takes additional time and can add additional costs related to 
26 
preparation, mailing, or legal services fees. Even then, due to inconsistent adjudication, USCIS 
27 
may still reject the application under the new policy based on perceived deficiencies that were not

13 
146.  As a result, the rejection policy is arbitrary and capricious and violates the APA. 
14 
COUNT III 
15 
Violation of the APA 
16  (Notice and Comment Rulemaking) 
 
17 
147.  All the foregoing allegations are repeated and realleged as though fully set forth 
18 
herein. 
19 
148.  Defendants’ new policy represents a dramatic departure from past practice that 
20 
impacts the substantive rights of applicants. 
21 
22  149.  This new policy imposes new obligations on applicants for immigration benefits 
23 
and results in grave consequences for applicants whose applications are rejected. 
24 
150.  Under the APA, new agency rules—regardless of whether they reverse a prior 
25 
policy—must go through notice and comment rulemaking. See 5 U.S.C. § 553. 
26 
151.  The rejection policy is a legislative rule that required notice and comment 
27 
28 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR             
 
INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF - 27           
        
 

Case 3:20-cv-08143   Document 1   Filed 11/19/20   Page 29 of 31
 
1  rulemaking.  
2 
152.  No other exception to notice and comment rulemaking applies to this policy. 
3 
153.  Defendants implemented the rejection policy without notice-and-comment 
4 
rulemaking, in violation of the APA. 
5 
COUNT IV 
6 
Violation of the APA 
(Notice Requirement) 
7 
 
8  154.  All the foregoing allegations are repeated and realleged as though fully set forth 
9  herein. 
10 
155.  Even if the rejection policy did not require notice and comment rulemaking, the 
11 
policy is either a “rule[] of procedure,” “substantive rule of general applicability,” “statement of 
12 
general policy,” or “interpretation[] of general applicability” that requires publication in the 
13 
Federal Register. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(1).  
14 
156.  As relevant here, the Federal Register notice requirement serves the important 
15 
16  purpose of apprising applicants subject to an agency’s policy or procedural rules of how an agency 
17 
will treat an application. 
18 
157.  Defendants failed to provide notice of the rejection policy in the Federal Register. 
19 
158.  This failure has harmed Plaintiffs and class members in significant ways. Because 
20 
Defendants did not explain or inform the public about the policy in a meaningful way, Defendants 
21 
rejected and continue to reject thousands of applications pursuant to the new policy.  
22 
23  COUNT V 
Violation of the APA 
24  (Not in Accordance with Law – Violation of Agency Regulations) 
 
25 
159.   All the foregoing allegations are repeated and realleged as though fully set forth 
26 
herein. 
27 
160.  Under the APA, a court may set aside agency action that is “not in accordance with 
28 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR             
 
INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF - 28           
        
 

Case 3:20-cv-08143   Document 1   Filed 11/19/20   Page 30 of 31
 
1  law.”  5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A). Agency regulations are law that bind and govern an agency’s 
2 
conduct. 
3 
161.  The rejection policy violates agency regulations that govern the adjudication of 
4 
applications because those regulations limit the bases on which USCIS may reject an application. 
5 
See 8 C.F.R. § 103.2(a)(7)(ii). While USCIS may reject applications that are not “[f]iled in 
6 
compliance with the regulations governing the filing of the specific application,” the regulations 
7 
8  governing most forms do not require an applicant to complete every single field.  
9  162.  In addition, USCIS’s rejection policy conflicts with the instructions for many of the 
10 
forms at issue, which were formally published after notice and comment. Under agency 
11 
regulations, these instructions are “incorporated into the regulations.” 8 C.F.R. § 103.2(a)(1). By 
12 
disregarding the instructions, USCIS’s actions are not in accordance with law. 
13 
14  PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
15 
WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs respectfully request that the Court: 
16 
a.  Assume jurisdiction over this matter; 
17 
b.  Certify a class pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 in accordance with this 
18 
  Complaint’s allegations; 
19 
c.  Declare that Defendants’ rejection of immigration benefits applications based on the 
20 
  rejection policy violates the Administrative Procedure Act; 
21 
22  d.  Permanently enjoin Defendant USCIS from rejecting any immigration benefits 
23    application based on the rejection policy; 
24 
e.  Order USCIS to issue or reissue a receipt notice using the date on which the initial 
25 
application was filed, not the date that an application was re-filed, for any application that 
26 
was or will be rejected (or for which a filing receipt was not issued) because of the 
27 
28 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT FOR             
 
INJUNCTIVE AND DECLARATORY RELIEF - 29           
        
 

Case 3:20-cv-08143   Document 1   Filed 11/19/20   Page 31 of 31
 
1  rejection policy; 
2 
f.  Award Plaintiffs’ counsel reasonable attorneys’ fees under the Equal Access to Justice 
3 
  Act, and any other applicable statute or regulation; and  
4 
g.  Grant such further relief as the Court deems just, equitable, and appropriate.  
5 
6  Respectfully submitted, 
 
7

documents.text:
Case 4:20-cv-08143-HSG   Document 43-1   Filed 07/19/21   Page 1 of 12
 
1 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE 
2 
NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
3 
SAN FRANCISCO/OAKLAND DIVISION 
4 
 
5 
AKHILESH R. VANGALA; I.S.A.; and KENNY M.  Case No. 20-cv-08143-HSG 
6  CASTANEDA PENATE, on behalf of themselves and  
 
all others similarly situated,  
7 
  
 
Plaintiffs, 
8 
SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT 
9  v. 
10  U.S. CITIZENSHIP AND IMMIGRATION SERVICES 
and U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND 
11  SECURITY,  
12 
Defendants. 
13 
 
14 
 
15 
SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT 
16 
This Settlement Agreement is entered into by and between Akhilesh R. Vangala, I.S.A., and 
17 
18  Kenny M. Castaneda Penate (“Plaintiffs”), and United States Citizenship and Immigration Services 
19  (“USCIS”) and Department of Homeland Security (“DHS”) (collectively “Defendants”).  Plaintiffs 
20 
and Defendants are referred to collectively herein as the “Parties.”  Out of a mutual desire to resolve 
21 
all of the claims in the above-captioned case (the “Action”) without need for further litigation and 
22 
without admission of any liability, the Parties hereby stipulate and agree as follows: 
23 
I.  RECITALS 
24 
WHEREAS: 
25 
26  1.  On November 19, 2020, Plaintiffs filed this putative class action alleging that USCIS, a 
component of DHS, implemented policies of rejecting immigration benefit requests if any 
27  field on certain multi-page applications was left blank (hereinafter “No Blank Space 
28  1 
 
   

Case 4:20-cv-08143-HSG   Document 43-1   Filed 07/19/21   Page 2 of 12
 
1 
Rejection Policy”); and that the process by which USCIS adopted the No Blank Space 
2  Rejection Policy and implemented it violated the Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”);   
 
3 
2.  Plaintiffs are three noncitizens who each had a benefit request rejected pursuant to the No 
Blank Space Rejection Policy. Plaintiffs brought this action on behalf of themselves and 
4 
sought to certify a class of all individuals who had submitted benefit requests, or would 
5  submit benefit requests, that had been or would be rejected by USCIS pursuant to the No 
Blank Space Rejection Policy;  
6 
 
3.  Although Plaintiffs’ Complaint was filed as a putative class action and Plaintiffs filed a 
7 
motion for class certification on November 19, 2020, briefing has not been completed and 
no class has been certified; 
8 
 
9  4.  Shortly after the lawsuit was filed, the Parties agreed to discuss settlement and, while such 
discussions were ongoing, Defendant USCIS agreed to and did halt the No Blank Space 
10 
Rejection Policy on December 22, 2020, and Plaintiffs agreed to postpone filing a motion 
for preliminary injunctive relief; 
11 
 
12  5.  Defendants have identified 43,501 submissions of USCIS Form I-589, Application for 
Asylum and for Withholding of Removal, and 17,000 submissions of USCIS Form I-918, 
13  Petition for U Nonimmigrant Status, that may have been rejected pursuant to the No Blank
